Hi there 5_c_d.

You asked me to answer in this thread why I need both Signal and Slack. I work in a company with 50 employees all over the world and we need continuous communications. Slack has channels and an advanced thread and sub-thread interface which we use extensively. So channels is a must. And everything must be searchable, both dialog and data. If good group video conferencing was available that would be a great feature also although we use Skype for that simply because it works, and works relatively well.

If Signal should want to compete with Slack the channel features must be added. That is the main feature keeping us on Slack. Currently I use Signal for all IM purposes, even with colleagues who I communicate with outside of work. On the other hand, if Signal does approach Slack as far as features go, and on top of that offers group video chat like Skype we would switch although it would be hard without the ability to move Slack data over to Signal. To be honest, I do not see how you would be able to do all this, but it would be very impressive if you tried, and beyond great if you succeeded.

And of course, totally cross platform! We need MacOS, Windows, Linux, Android and iOS. If one is missing we‚Äôre out.

Android Police ‚Äì 13 Mar 25

Your WhatsApp group chats could soon be less chaotic thanks to threaded replies

WhatsApp might soon start grouping all message replies under a new dedicated expandable view

I‚Äôd like to +1 this feature request. Specifically, it would be great to be able to, inside of a larger group chat A, seamlessly create a temporary sub-group chat B which is only viewable from inside A, which members of A can freely view and contribute to, and which is also seamlessly deleted/archived at a future date.

For example, I‚Äôm in a ~30 person group chat for a local organization. A few people start talking about the specifics of an event we‚Äôre planning the upcoming weekend, or maybe someone requests feedback on a public piece they‚Äôve prepared, and we‚Äôd like to allow those discussions to happen without cluttering the main chat. Often the cross-over from belongs-in-the-group-chat to needs-its-own-chat happens organically so having a seamless ‚Äústart thread‚Äù feature (like the one in Discord) would be helpful.

I would also lijke to see threads. This may even encourage new users. I recently tried to find a messaging app in which we could create a group for our community, which is secure and could also support threads. That is not an easy task.

And threads are really needed in many groups (parents from one class, shared interest teams etc.), as very often different topics are beingg discussed at the same time. It is really hard to follow different discussions when they are all in the same bucket.

Add threads/topics and Signal will be a no-brainer messaging app for communities.
